title: The Burning Bush
shortSummary: Exodus chapter 3 recounts the pivotal moment when God reveals Himself to Moses through the miraculous burning bush and commissions him to deliver Israel from Egyptian bondage. This chapter introduces God's holy name and His covenant faithfulness, setting the stage for the Exodus and God's redemptive plan for His people.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The Hebrew chosen by God to lead Israel out of Egypt; in this chapter, he encounters God at the burning bush and receives his divine commission.

keyCharacters.name: Jethro
keyCharacters.description: Moses' father-in-law and priest of Midian, whose flock Moses tends when he encounters God.

keyCharacters.name: The Angel of the LORD
keyCharacters.description: The divine messenger who appears to Moses in the burning bush, signifying God's presence and initiating the call to deliver Israel.

definitions.definition: A miraculous bush that was on fire but not consumed, symbolizing God's holy presence and eternal nature.
God’s self-existent and eternal name revealed to Moses, emphasizing His unchanging and sovereign nature.
A place set apart by God's presence, requiring reverence and purity, as indicated by Moses removing his sandals.
A phrase describing the fertility and abundance of the Promised Land, symbolizing God's provision and blessing.

outline.heading: Moses Encounters God at Horeb
outline.description: Moses tends Jethro’s flock and discovers the burning bush on Mount Horeb, where God reveals His presence and commands reverence by declaring the ground holy.

outline.heading: God Reveals His Identity
outline.description: God identifies Himself as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, declares His awareness of Israel’s suffering, and commissions Moses to deliver His people with the promise of His presence.

outline.heading: The Divine Name Revealed
outline.description: Moses questions God’s name, and God reveals the sacred name 'I AM THAT I AM,' underscoring His eternal, self-existent nature and covenant faithfulness.

outline.heading: Instructions for Israel and Pharaoh
outline.description: God instructs Moses to gather Israel’s elders and confront Pharaoh, foretelling resistance but assuring victory through God’s mighty acts and provision.

application: Approach God with reverence and humility, recognizing His holiness as Moses did by removing his sandals.
Trust in God's presence and promises when facing difficult tasks or calling, just as Moses was assured 'I will be with thee.'
Declare and rely on the eternal and unchanging nature of God, who reveals Himself as 'I AM THAT I AM,' the foundation of our faith.
Obey God's call promptly, even when feeling inadequate, knowing He equips and empowers His servants for His purposes.

keyVerses.text: And he said, Draw not nigh hither: put off thy shoes from off thy feet, for the place whereon thou standest is holy ground.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the holiness of God's presence and the proper reverence required when encountering Him.

keyVerses.text: And God said unto Moses, I AM THAT I AM: and he said, Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, I AM hath sent me unto you.
keyVerses.significance: God reveals His eternal and self-existent name, assuring Moses and Israel of His unchanging nature and authority.

keyVerses.text: And he said, Certainly I will be with thee; and this shall be a token unto thee, that I have sent thee: When thou hast brought forth the people out of Egypt, ye shall serve God upon this mountain.
keyVerses.significance: God promises His presence and support to Moses, encouraging obedience and faith in the mission ahead.

keyVerses.text: Come now therefore, and I will send thee unto Pharaoh, that thou mayest bring forth my people the children of Israel out of Egypt.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the divine commissioning of Moses as God's chosen deliverer of Israel.
